item.title: Building Better Habits: My Take on Atomic Habits
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
Just finished reading Atomic Habits by James Clear, and honestly, it’s one of those books that makes you want to immediately reorganize your entire life. Rating it a solid 9/10.

The Core Concept

The book revolves around the compounding effect - small changes that seem insignificant at first but compound into remarkable results over time. Clear argues that you don’t need massive changes; you need consistent, tiny improvements.

Key Takeaways That Hit Different

Environment is Everything

Your environment plays a critical role in defining habit behaviors. The most significant contributor? Your visual environment. Want to break a bad habit? Break your exposure to the cue that triggers it in the first place.

item.title: Dune: Overhyped or Underappreciated?
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
Finally got around to reading Dune by Frank Herbert after Harrison kept recommending it. My honest take? It’s… complicated.

The Good

The first book is genuinely good. Herbert created this incredibly detailed universe with complex politics, ecology, and mysticism all woven together. The world-building is impressive, and you can see why it’s considered a sci-fi classic.

The movie (at least the first one) was visually stunning and did justice to the source material. Denis Villeneuve really understood the assignment.

item.title: The Three-Body Problem: Hard Sci-Fi That Hits Different
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
The Three-Body Problem by Cixin Liu is the kind of sci-fi that makes you question everything about humanity’s place in the universe. Rating: 8.1/10 (yeah, a lot of my sci-fi reads end up around there).

What Makes It Special

This isn’t your typical Western sci-fi. Liu brings a distinctly Chinese perspective to concepts like fate vs. free will, and it’s refreshing. The book feels less about individual heroism and more about humanity as a whole facing an existential threat.

item.title: The Sovereign Individual: Prescient or Pretentious?
item.author: deadfast@proton.io (deadfast)
item.description:
The Sovereign Individual by James Dale Davidson and Lord William Rees-Mogg is one of those books that either feels like prophecy or pretentious rambling, depending on when you read it. Rating: 7.8/10.

The Central Thesis

Written in 1997, the book predicts the rise of digital currencies, remote work, and the decline of nation-states. The authors argue that technology will eventually allow individuals to become “sovereign” - free from traditional government control and taxation.
